data.title: Think New Mexico
data.text:
Think New Mexico is beyond excited to welcome Katie Gutierrez to the staff as our first Tax, Budget & Economic Development Reform Director!

Katie is from San Antonito, New Mexico, where her family has been farming for generations. A PhD candidate in Economics at the University of New Mexico, she studies the impact of taxes and policy changes on people’s health and wellbeing, with a focus on social justice and reducing health disparities. Katie is a Robert Wood Johnson Foundation Health Policy Research Scholar alumna, a UNM Center for Social Policy alumna, and a former organizer with the United Graduate workers of UNM. She most recently was a Visiting Professor of Economics at Williams College. ... See MoreSee Less

We are delighted to welcome our final summer 2024 Leadership Intern, Ayvret van Waveren!

Ayvret was born in Santa Fe, NM and has always considered it home. Growing up, he spent 10 years in Almaty, Kazakhstan, and 8 years in Muscat, Oman. He graduated from The American International School of Muscat, where he earned the Political Science Student of the Year Award. Ayvret is now a rising senior at Amherst College, studying Political Science with a concentration in Economics. He is currently writing his thesis, "New Mexico at a Crossroads," which analyzes major issues affecting the state, including the struggling economy, high violent crime rate, and underperforming schools, and explores potential policy solutions to address those issues. Ayvret previously interned at the First Judicial District Attorney's Office in Santa Fe and with New Mexico Senate Majority Leader Peter Wirth. After earning his undergraduate degree, Ayvret intends to go to law school and then pursue a career in law and New Mexico politics and policy. ... See MoreSee Less

Oregon high schoolers will have to take and pass stand-alone classes on financial literacy and college and career preparation to graduate, starting with this fall’s sophomores.

...

Integrating financial literacy and college and career preparation materials into existing classes would “perpetuate the current practice of rushed or incomplete instruction as teachers are not given enough time or training to provide instruction in the new subject matters,” Senior Deputy Legislative Counsel Hannah Lai wrote in response to lawmakers’ query. Legislators made it clear that they expected semester-long stand-alone courses, she advised, and the state board did not have authority to deviate from that directive.

...

“Integrated means lost, and that is the key,” Scheinman said. “If you integrate the topic as a part of other classes, the teacher has no real incentive to be familiar with the material and it won’t matter too much. A student can still get an 80%, based on their knowledge of other things.”

Scheinman framed the issue in economic terms. District can spend the money now to help students learn about how to manage their finances or students can pay the price later, when that lack of knowledge comes back to hurt them, he said.

Some students, too, have backed the concept. Newport High School student Andrea Merino Comejo told lawmakers this year that taking a financial literacy class gave her a practical leg up. She said she learned “how to manage my money, how to build credit with a card [and] it has trained me how to buy a car from a private party. I can already see how it is getting me ready for my future finance decisions as an adult.”

... See MoreSee Less

Despite pushback, Oregon schools will require stand-alone classes on financial literacy, post-high school plans

www.oregonlive.com

Oregon high schoolers will have to take and pass stand-alone classes on financial literacy and college and career preparation to graduate, starting with the class of 2027.
